Package com.teksystems.salestaxexercise.tax.canada

Class CanadianTaxJurisdiction

java.lang.Object
com.teksystems.salestaxexercise.tax.AbstractTaxJurisdiction
com.teksystems.salestaxexercise.tax.canada.CanadianTaxJurisdiction
All Implemented Interfaces:
TaxJurisdiction
public class CanadianTaxJurisdiction
extends AbstractTaxJurisdiction
Singleton class that represents the Canadian federal tax jurisdiction. NOTE: in a real system, there likely wouldn't be a need for this class, or at least for all of the constants inside it to be constants. All of this country-specific info could be loaded from a data source and used to create a country-specific instance of a more generic concrete class
Author:
Andrew

  • Field Details

    • ROUNDING_MODE

      public static final java.math.RoundingMode ROUNDING_MODE
      The default rounding mode for Canadian taxes. Canadian taxes are always rounded up by default.

    • ROUNDING_RULE

      public static final MoneyRoundingRule ROUNDING_RULE
      The custom rounding rule for Canadian taxes. Canadian taxes are always rounded up to the nearest multiple of 5 cents by default.

  • Method Details

    • getInstance

      public static CanadianTaxJurisdiction getInstance()
      Get the Singleton instance of this class.
      Returns:
      The Singleton CanadianTaxJurisdiction object.

    • getSalesTax

      public SalesTax getSalesTax()
      Get the sales tax object for Canada. Getter here exclusively so this tax object can be used for unit testing.
      Returns:
      The Canadian sales tax.

    • getImportSalesTax

      public ImportSalesTax getImportSalesTax()
      Get the import duty object for Canada. Getter here exclusively so this tax object can be used for unit testing.
      Returns:
      The Canadian import duty.

    • getTaxableCategoryFor

      public TaxableCategory getTaxableCategoryFor​(SellableItem sellableItem)
      Get the tax category of a specific product or service in this jurisdiction.

      TODO: SOLID design principles suggest maybe this shouldn't be here. There may be tax jurisdictions where all taxes are universally applied to all goods and services, meaning there is no need to keep track of categories. So this method should be split out in to a separate interface that extends this one, specifically for jurisdictions that require categories.

      This implementation will not allow this method to ever return null, will always return TaxableCategory.OTHER if no category can be determined for any reason.
      Specified by:
      getTaxableCategoryFor in interface TaxJurisdiction
      Overrides:
      getTaxableCategoryFor in class AbstractTaxJurisdiction
      Parameters:
      sellableItem - the item to be sold
      Returns:
      The taxable category for this item in this jurisdiction. Never null for this implementation.
      Throws:
      java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if sellableItem is null.
